I used to work for a man who owned a large pecan orchard here in Palestine Texas. If the pecan husk looks like it is open but the pecan does not fall when you shake the tree then those are bad pecans. Normally it is because a fungus has gotten on them during development from too much humidity and not enough air flow between the trees and it kills the juices that circulate to the developing nut. The other reason is from moths that lay their eggs in the new tiny baby pecan, and the larvae eats the inside of the developing nut.  In the first case then that never finished maturing so it never really completely let go of the hull. In the second case the nut never finished developing because of being eaten from the inside. The first doesn't fall when you shake the tree so the bad ones actually stay off of the ground. The second one that was being eaten internally falls but is extremely lite and these are the ones that are blown out by the air sorter where the heavier mature ones don't get blown out. 👍🏻

I would guess, that it does not make a huge difference in which direction the tree is shaken, because the thin twigs act like a rope. Take a rope, 2 or 3 meters long, and make kind of a two dimensional sine wave at one end, while the rope is hanging straight down. Watch the rope while doing that. Do it left and right, and then shift your movement 90 degrees, compare both cases. It will also work while the rope is laying on  the floor, it is just more difficult to shift the movement by 90 degrees while having gravity. I guess it is the same for the tree, just upside-down compared to the hanging rope.

Wow!  In about the 1980s there was an Australian TV program on in South Africa, called "Beyond 2000".  I did not miss an episode!  This was about technology being developed at the time that was thought to be mainstream in the years 2000 and onward.  This idea of shaking a tree to harvest it was then being developed.  I seem to remember, at the time, they mentioned about treating the trees with a hormone which would ensure the nuts would open and ready for shaking.  They also used tarpaulins under the trees to catch the harvest, elevating the need for the machine that pics them up.  Very interesting to see the whole process!

Spitballing ideas about why the late harvest. Short answer - Climate Change. Longer (still broad) hypothesis - Pecan trees are relatives to deciduous hickory trees. the pecans are fruits/seeds being ejected from flowers that open up at the change in seasons. Late September is when you expect the turn from summer to fall through quite literally through the fall equinox. The flowers don't open because of temperatures being too warm despite having the right amount of radiation from the sun. (flowering proteins could be temperature and light sensitive. Different breeds of pecans could extend the variation to prevent seedling competition) The seed ejection gets desynced so harvest season comes later than expected. Harvest yield might be lower as well because of the desync.

Here is my theory on why going 90° out of phase has no noticable effect. I think this is because the center of mass of the tree is never perfectly inline with axis of oscillation, (I think that's the right term) thus a torque is always applied along the trunk and a feedback loop incurs so you end up with a rotational effect.

To think about this in a simplified form: stick a pen thru a roll of tape or something similar and by only using the pen, attempt to move the roll of tape up and down with out it rotating around the pen. It's impossible because you will never get it perfectly normal to the inside of the roll such that all horizontal forces cancel out. Now rotate the ring 90°, nothing changes because you still end up in the same feedback loop. This is an example of harmonic motion, right?

Direction of shaking the tree doesn't matter because the vibrational frequency at the large base of the tree is so high that as the vibrations move through the smaller limbs, those limbs reach their resonant frequencies which naturally will cause them to move in whichever direction is easiest. If the vibration moved in much longer frequencies and higher amplitude. then all the limbs are more likely to move in the direction of the source, and then directional vibration would matter but be less likely to shake the nuts off the tree.

For the cracking machine, you can also have 2 plates, one still, one rotating. Both have "teeth" that come and break the shells of the nuts... nuts get in between from a hole in the center of the top plate (which stays still). Goes quite fast... you just need to sieve big and small nuts apart before, so you avoid excessive breaking of the bigger nuts. You then adapt the space between the 2 plates according to the size of the nuts :)

Another engineer here out in Arkansas, I actually went out last fall and helped out at a pecan farm out of curiosity on weekends. There is only a couple of differences between the larger scale operations and the family ran.

The shaker was a stand alone unit, and as such wasn't on PTO. Once the pecans were collected (basically same machine for collecting) the pecans were collected directly into a trailer which had a hopper on the bottom for feeding into the blower. The air velocity of the blower was adjustable via counter weight, which allowed you to get different pecan grades (IE you could fill 4,000 lb bags with higher quality nuts first for higher price per lb). They didn't shell pecans on site, they were loaded onto semis and sold to a company in Oklahoma who payed based off of the quality of the nuts in the bag.
No squirrels here.
Watching the tree almost grow from the release of the weight was fascinating to see in slow motion

About shaking trees, that's what they also do with olive trees here in Spain. They still hit the branches with long sticks and they also use some kind of mechanical shakers, which look like weed eaters but with a pitch fork at the end instead of wire, but they use kind of a 2.0 version from what they have in the video, as when the shaker is in place, it has some kind of cloth that mechanically goes around the tree, kind of a bat wing that finally looks like an umbrella upside down. This is in order to catch all olives before they hit the ground.

Also, when doing it by hand or "mechanical pitch forks", they use nets, kind of fishing nets, on the ground so it's easier to pick them all. I don't know why they wouldn't do it here, I guess it saves a step in the cleaning process but... who knows.

Hi Destin, about the vibrating branch, I think you're looking at a resonating vibration mode. The higher up the vibration goes up in to tree, the more the vibration gets damped out. Resonating modes don't damp out as quickly though, so high up in the tree the vibration modes of the tree and its branches are prevalent. Because you have damping in the tree these vibration modes will get excited independently of the angle you shake the tree. Actually it would be really interesting if you can shake the tree at different speed, so that you basically do a frequency sweep of the tree.
Oh and yeah doing this manually you get way more striking from both axis

Reminds me of growing up on one of grandpa's cherry orchards. They're cherries, so they're soft and can't hit the ground, which is another problem to solve. So they run around with two big machines, the shaker and the catcher, with giant tarps that fit together and funnel all the cherries onto the catcher. Shaker shakes, it's pretty much identical to the tractor here, aside from being a dedicated machine instead of a tractor attachment. The catcher is really interesting, though. Everything funnels down onto it, and it has a conveyer belt that feeds everything into a water-filled tote in the back, to transport the cherries. On the end it drops everything over an air blower to knock most of the leaves and twigs and bad cherries out of it, then when the tote's full they drop it, swap it for a new one, and a tractor hauls the full one off. I was just a little guy, so I was on tote filling and cleaning duty. Fill them about a third full, and when they're brought back we scraped everything that floated- more leaves and rotten cherries- out of them, then we capped a lid on them and they were loaded onto the truck. Grandpa had something like 200 acres back in the day. I grew up in great grandpa's house, on a 20 acre plot. Never helped with the plums (We always just called them prunes, because they were low-water content pruning plums) but I think that was the same process.

Regarding the tree shaking in the same way whether you approach it one way or 90 degrees apart, this reminded me of gravitational waves: a gravitational wave is identical when rotated by 90 degrees, but is most different when rotated 45 degrees (since compression one way looks like stretching in the perpendicular direction, and the wave alternates stretching and compressing). It's not clear to me that a similar thing would be happening here, but I'm still curious to see if it makes any difference if you shake the tree at a 45 degree angle the second time

Let me start off by saying this is not a criticism of your video and was not something you'd know before this. You may notice how much the quality of the youtube video drops when you have a scene where a lot of leaves are dropping. This is actually a byproduct of Youtubes algorithm to lower the storage required for the video! So while it may leak great in raw quality on your screen, on Youtube it's a little blurry. Interesting enough this effect is caused by the random change of pixels (think a snow storm and confetti)

Not a physics PhD, but my take on the pecan tree branches shaking the same way between the orthogonal shaking angles:

Each section of the tree all the way up to the tips of the branches has it's own reaction forces determined by it's structural orientation relative to the other parts of the tree it's connected to.

As the force travels up the tree, the resonant system of each section reacts to the applied movement with the elastic rebound characteristic of it's structural orientation, taking the energy from the original axis of motion and redirecting it into it's own particular direction, becoming closer to what you might term a "specific resonance" (a shape in the spatial domain, for a particular energy/frequency) of each branch.

So by the time it reaches the top, the direction of the original mechanical input is mostly gone, its energy incrementally "harvested" to produce the branches' own characteristic vibrations.

The trees are motion filters, they're going to shake much the same way from any input direction because of the way they grow.  Part is in tension and part is in compression.  Since the shaker is coupled to the tree and not the ground it will obey the root anchorage pattern.  Its far more likely to get a different pattern of shake if you raise or lower the shaker than changing the direction of input.   I would suggest, in the long run, that slowly finding the direction with the most thorough shaking then marking that down would be better for the lifespan health of the trees as it would allow much lower input to achieve the same results - resulting in less root stress and trauma to the vertical roots.

I have some experience with virbration analysis. The reason why the branches move similarly with the rotated shaker input is because the frequency of the vibration does not change. A flexible body does have certain mode shapes / normal modes which are triggered at certain frequencies. If the frequency would change the body or branch in this case would move according to a different mode shape for that frequency. Anyways, always cool to see you looking for science in everyday places. As always, inspiring video!

Vowels are magic, they have a long and a short sound. The vowel at the back says to the vowel in front, "Don't be short, be long". Hence "Pee-can". The vowel at the back "a" can jump over one consonant (the "c") and say to the "e" in front, you have to be a long vowel "eee" sound. There is no vowel behind the "a" so that vowel stays short. Also, "Macramé"  "mac-ar-mee" French pronunciation of a Turkish word, originating from Arabic. The joys of English being the multi-national language that it is but which Noah Webster in his ignorance totally butchered.

'PTO' -- Power Take-Off -- a rotating shaft connected to the tractor's drive train (crankshaft, flywheel, clutch & transmission) or sometimes run off a hydraulic fluid pump (similar to power steering pumps).  Various 'powered' implements are connected to the PTO shaft (rotating tillers, excavators, sprayers, mowers, harvesters, sweepers, augers, etc.) eliminating the complexity and weight of additional motors or engines for each device.  Simpler devices likes plows, rollers, harrows, etc. would probably not use the PTO.

There's a possibility of increasing harvesting efficiency using this.

The top most branches showing nearly identical vibration when the tree is excited in two perpendicular axes: I guess happens due to transfer of energy through the lower branches via the path of least resistance. Branches have different stiffnesses in different axes due to their geometry. Which means they'll tend vibrate more along that low stiffness axis only. There will be slight mode mixing nonetheless. Lower branches act as vibrational filters. Quite fascinating.

Every November, I used to battle squirrels at my grandmothers house in Louisiana for pecans. I would get up before dawn and would have bags and buckets. I would crawl on the ground in long rows, methodically picking up all the pecans and I could feel ones deeper in grass with my knees. Because I took every single pecan, squirrels would scream at me. I would fill up 30 paper bags after a couple days of sunrise to sunset work, pile them in moms station wagon and she would drive us into town to sell at the bulk wholesaler. I would take all that cash and go buy fireworks. I’m jealous looking at all this machinery!

Several major media outlets in Finland gave front-page coverage on a forum discussing forced organ harvesting in China held in Helsinki on September 19, 2019. Finland’s most popular newspapers, the Helsinki Daily (Helsingin Sanomat) and HSL (the top Swedish newspaper in Finland), reported on the forum.

The reason for the rise of organ transplantation in China, the response of the international community, and people’s indignation at the Chinese Communist Party’s (CCP) state-sanctioned organ harvesting from living Falun Gong practitioners were all discussed during the forum.



Helsinki Daily's online and print reports on the forum held in Helsinki on September 19, 2019

HSL (the best-selling Swedish newspaper in Finland) reported on the forum.

The reports stated, “The CCP started the persecution of Falun Gong in 1999. Since then, the rate of organ transplantation in China has risen rapidly. The country’s voluntary organ donation system was not established until 2013.

“The CCP acknowledged the use of organs from death-row prisoners for organ transplants and stated it had stopped doing that in early 2015. However, the extent of executions has not yet reached a level that explains the high rate of organ transplantation.

“Human rights lawyers, doctors, and activists investigating live organs collected multiple pieces of evidence. According to them, China conducts 60,000 to 100,000 organ transplants every year through organs taken from prisoners of conscience. Most of the organs were taken from Falun Gong practitioners.

“In recent years, people suspected that the organs of Uighur Muslims living in Xinjiang are stolen. Uighurs are undergoing health tests and blood tests. According to [Enver Tohti, a former Uighur surgeon who witnessed the Chinese regime’s harvesting of organs from prisoners], the purpose of the test was to form a live bank of human organs along with information about Tibetan and Christians of underground churches.

“However, most of the evidence proves that the organs are from Falun Gong practitioners. There are 800,000 to 3 million people in Chinese concentration camps and prisons. The limited transparency of these camps means that there are no exact figures [about] the seriousness of the problem.”

We just had 4 pecan trees in our back lot when I was growing up. And at 5 years old my dad gave me a kid sized single shot .22 and taught me shooting safety, ethics and how to shoot so I could, each year thereafter, ahem... 'remove' the squirrels that devistated the crop.
See, a squirrel get in the tree before the pecans are ripe and pulls the husked nut off, takes a bite and because it's bitter drops it on the ground and gets another one... A single squirrel can strip a tree in a couple of days.
I actually liked doing it, sitting in a lawn chair out under the trees, with a snack Mom had made, after school, reading a book and looking up every so often for any squirrels. It would take about a week to eradicate any local squirrels that knew where the trees were. And the squirrels I shot got fried up and eaten, yum.

I grew up in Oklahoma and in the 1980s I had an elderly friend who had a pecan orchard. He made his own tree shakers and pecan crackers. He also had a few date trees in the orchard, but there were about 100 pecan trees. He was an amazing guy, one of the old farmer types who could fix anything or make anything he needed from scratch. I think he just sold his pecans in bulk to a company that processed, packaged and sold them because he didn't have any packaged products I knew of and definitely didn't sell direct to consumers. It was mostly just a retirement hobby for him. He was a retired postman and his wife was a teacher. Lots of good memories there.

The machine uses an unbalanced rotating mass so it doesn't produce a vibration along one axis. I wouldn't expect anything to change if you rotate 90 degrees.

For automated machines like the shelling one it's very common to use compressed air for actuation. It's readily available, reliable, and reduces moving parts. If you had a spring you'd have to tear down the whole machine when it broke.

When I grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area, french prune trees were popular. They harvested them with a similar machine. The trees were probably 10-15 ft tall, which made it possible to not only vibrate, but to build a giant rubber cone to shake and catch the fruit at the same time. It was split into two halves, and you'd back it around a tree, clamp it shut, then vibrate. Personally, fresh off the tree is far better than dried! Modern prune orchards have changed since then, but I'm sure there's still some retired farmer using his 70's-80's era equipment to harvest.

Trees have years that they will grow a very large number of nuts called a mast year. They grow a normal amount of nuts for 4-5 years so the local bird and squirrel population becomes accustomed to the amount of nuts grown, then in the 5th or 6th year, they will grow a much larger number of nuts that increases the chance that there will be some nuts left over to germinate into trees. Tree species like oak and beech will co-ordinate across great distances and all share the same mast year, how they do this is not fully understood.

My brother in law harvests his olives in much the same way. The difference is they lay tarpaulin sheets around the olive tree, then shake the olives out. They can then pull the corners of the sheets together and the olives gather in the centre of the sheet where they are put into bags and crates for processing.
What surprised me is they are taken to the village press where they extract the oil. Very few farmers on their island have their own press.

The fact that this harvesting machine is called "Savage" is just nuts.

In Catalonia (Spain) we have a traditional desert called "Nous Garrapinyades" ("nous" means nuts, pecans for example). We basically prepare caramel from brown sugar and we sir-fry the nuts in it, so the nuts become coated in caramel. ("Garrapinyar" means this process). The result is spectacular. And it's actually very easy to prepare. We also do this process with sunflower seeds. If you ever read this comment and feel curious about it, search "Nous Garrapinyades" on google and try it! I assure it will be worthwhile. And also, does this exist in other countries? Please let me know, i've been looking it up but I can't find any information. Have a nice day :)

When I was little. We (my mother, 2 older sisters, my older brother & myself) would go out to the farm (grandparents & aunt and uncles farm) to help gather pecans. The pecans were wild groves down by the river or within a half mile of it. We would end up bringing 6 or more full paper bags home with us. Then just sit at the kitchen table...cracking nuts....for hours upon hours...lol. All the broken ones would be ground up & then most was frozen. To this day, I HATE cracking pecans....lol

We used to harvest pecans by using the highly developed technology of waiting a murder of crows to fly by the trees.

There's be a few hundreds of crows who rushed the tree and stood on the branches for a few minutes, and the vibration from their landing, pecking and take off would make all the pecans drop.

If we didn't have crows that year, or a wind storm, or a hail storm, we'd have fun throwing big sticks at the branches. Accidents may or may not have happened :)

The axis doesn't matter because only the branches perfectly perpendicular with the axis of vibration are getting the full effect of the directional motion.  The rest of the branches aren't, but are still being shaken adequately to dislodge nuts--and even then those perpendicular branches would only benefit from  a change in the machine's axis if the perpendicular first pass was less effective due to swaying, and those unideal branches would be a rarity.
FYI to  actually see the high speed camera at work better, you need to view this video in 720p60.

The seasonal changes in loading on the branches, result in them becoming what is known as “reaction wood”, which no matter how large it is you do not use for dimension lumber, but can use for turning blanks.  The reaction wood has a lot of residual stresses in it, and it will move and split as you try to cut it to a dimension.

"Braiding Sweetgrass" (author: Prof Robin Wall Kimmerer) has some excellent passages about the importance of pecans to Native American (First Nation) people.  Helped make hard winters survivable.  Note: Also in that book it's mentioned that trees can delay fruiting by years to starve out an abundance of critters eating it. When I was younger, I actually worked on a farm for a short time during pecan harvests. My first job was pick up the large sticks and branches. There were usually two of us kids who would have that job, and one person who could drive would pull a big trailer around so we could throw the sticks/branches into it. After the harvester filled the dump trailer, we would go back to the barn to sort the pecans. I had the job of making sure all the pecans were being dumped as quick as possible, so I would literally climb to the top of the upended dump trailer and sort of slide down with the pecans so that they didn't hit any issues where the pecans stopped feeding onto the conveyor belt. I honestly think I got that job because I was a bit too short to help on the conveyor.

I could write ten pages of comment with stories of my grandmother's pecan trees (pronounced "p'con" emphasis on the 'o' and barely pronounced 'n'' by my little French "Na'nee" borne in New Orleans). In something like the early 30s, my Pawpa (Grandfather) planted a single pecan tree in the back yard of their home on the Mississippi Gulf coast. Over the years, the squirrels Na'nee loved so much were responsible for the sprouting of several more trees in both back and front yard. Every spring Na'nee would pull up dozens of saplings trying to keep the tree count to three in the back and two in the front. A few of those saplings account for the three trees now growing in my brother's yard in North Carolina and one in an old front yard of mine in Virginia Beach. Somewhere I have a photo of a little, four foot 10in French lady, snow white hair and wearing a pith helmet, chasing squirrels out of her pecan trees with a 25 foot aluminum pole. This was her fall time vigilance that went on for as long as I can remember. Every Christmas my mom would receive a box with about 25 lbs of shelled and picked pecans. It also included a dozen or so jars of preserved figs from Na'nee's 100 year old fig tree, but that's another story.
P.S. Try cooking some bare, naked chicken on the grill, but instead of charcoal, make your fire with the fallen sticks and limbs of the pecan trees. Keep adding twigs and sticks slowly as the chicken cooks. You'll never use BBQ sauce again.

3 pounds for 20 bucks!!! Sahale snacks sells a small bag of valdosta pecans for about 7 dollars, for around 3 ounces. Granted, they spruce the pecans up a little bit, add some maple and a brown sugar...but that is really cheap. 1 pound should be 20 bucks. I grew up next to a neighbor like this man, who wasn't in it for a huge profit either. He had an 80 year old small grove of peaches and he sold a bushel of the best peaches I'd ever eaten in my life for 10 to 14 bucks...and it was a big bushel. That small orchard is around 120 years old now, and the trees have branches falling off every year due to the softball sized peaches not being groomed and just left to grow full till the weight snaps the branches...almost all those trees have perished since he passed away and nobody was left to continue maintaining the trees. He was a really good man too..didn't mind us as kids passing through his property to play in the river or hunt in his woods as long as we stopped and talked to him if we saw him. Since he passed away, his wife sold most of the old growth timbers and leased the fields out to a taxidermist who hunted all the game pretty much off it. It took them a few years to almost kill that place entirely...but my memories of how it was when Mr. McPhearson was alive won't ever die. It was a 6,000 acre old plantation property nobody lived on anymore, with two old houses that crumbled in on themselves...and many fields for farmer, and it stretch a few miles along the bend in a river in North Carolina. Melancholy is a wonderful, and terrible thing whenever I visit there these days.

The 90 degree shake doesn’t make much difference because limbs and branches have a dominant flex preference. Basically the direction the wood flexes easiest is going to always flex in that general direction with rapid resonant waves. It wood probably be different if it was a much slower shake. As an exaggerated example it’s like trying to flex a 2x4 in both directions and expect the same inflection.

What blows my mind is the thought process of the farmer. As tradesmen and professionals do they get caught in a process that is perfected and super efficient. When someone like Destin comes along and asks questions they can't immediately answer them but they do have the knowledge to tell you why they do or don't do something. My example is his shaking the tree in one direction. He answered like he didn't ever think of doing it in different directions but the truth is he knows why he don't but is caught in his perfected process and forgets why he don't do it that way even though he knows the answer. Shaking in two directions is ineffective and would not yield enough nuts for the time spent. The complexity of the brain and thought process and repetition. I believe farmers, tradesmen and blue collar workers are some of the smartest people on the planet.

Hey Destin, I grew up in the Niagara Falls/Welland Ontario region.  We had cherry trees, those are also harvested in a similar manner.  Two interesting things about this that I dont think I heard you mention.  An attacked tree will fruit better than one that has a rosy life, it fruits in response to the attack to ensure species regeneration.   Wind comes at a tree in all directions but if a tree only fortifies itself for one direction it will be in trouble so its response to wind is an average of all wind interactions, so shaking 90 degrees the tree reaction is the same. Great video Destin. For the mathematics of the shaking, what is happening is essentially a series of inverted double pendulums, constrained by the modulus of rigidity of the individual branches (possible topic for a video, as double pendulum systems are great examples of chaotic motion with a relatively simple setup). I really liked how you experimented with the 90° offset of the shaking energy impulse, though there is one more potential test that could be done: shake in both directions simultaneously. This would require a shaker modification, with the weight axle turned 90° to be horizontal vs vertical. In this way rather than imparting a single axis impulse of energy it would impart a circular impulse, essentially creating an inverted double Furuta pendulum setup which might have a higher degree of chaos displacement at the nut, or it might not since each branch connection point will have a preferred resonant frequency axis, so the Furuta effect may damp out. With the nature of chaotic systems, this would be both interesting to model and to experiment with. The other variable to experiment with is the speed of the shaking, controllable by the PTO driven RPM, to find the best resonant frequency for each tree...

I'm in my 70's and we did this by hand when we were teens and pre-teens with my father on grandparents properties. Our procedure was to spread out what tarps we had under the trees then climb and shake the limbs by hand the gather the nuts on the tarps and pickup all we could by hand. Probably like everyone else that was not mechanised, the variation my father did that I never saw anyone else do was. He would light the grass and leaves under each tree burning off and making it easier to pick up the pecans trapped by the grass. These we kept separate and we ate all of these we wanted as they were warm and roasted.
I'd like to know if anyone else did this. Many times getting to crack and eat roasted pecans was our only payment for our hard work! We also got pecans for my mother to use in her baking all year but most were sold by my grandparents as an additional cash crop for income. Please let me know in the comments if anyone else used our fire roasted procedure.

Oh, the memories.  There was a row of pecan trees between my junior high and the VA hospital in Montgomery.  About Thanksgiving time, my mother would take me over to the trees to pick pecans.  We would have to identify the husks in all the fallen leaves and then take them home.  We'd remove the husks and then crack the nuts - with a nutcracker.  Our hands would be stained and I would have nightmares about finding nuts in among the leaves.  But the pies my mother would make!  Divine!  Thanks for the trip down Memory Lane!

The best part of this entire video was the “punishment” part, and it reminds me of the my grandad and dad. My family ranches in the hill country of Texas, and rocks are everywhere. One of our punishments was throwing rocks out of the livestock pens. It was a never ending punishment. You could throw rocks out until there wasn’t a single one left, and a year later, from the animals churning up the dirt, there would be more. There are massive piles of stones outside of all of our pens, from both me and my dad’s childhoods.

I worked on an almond farm in Australia and they have the same sort of method. We had one person driving a shaker and another driving a sort of catcher. They would go either side of the tree and the shaker and the catcher extend things to sort of interlock. So when the tree shakes the nuts fell into the shaker which then went into a trailer using a conveyer belt. When the trailer was full a dumper truck would come and pick up all the nuts from the trailer. It was awesome work, if anyone is doing their visa for Aus and want to get a second year I would highly recommend Almond farming for 3 months, you make so much money too.

Is that vibration good for the trees? Or bad for them? My mom is a master gardener, and that's something I learned from her. Plants that grow outside, encountering wind, humans, and other animals grow to be stronger plants than plants that aren't exposed to environmental factors(and/or vibrations etc.). That's why it's recommended to touch your plants if you're growing them indoors, and to play music around them every once in while. There are studies that show music also has an effect on plants because of the vibrations.

Well I'll be damned - giant vibrator FOR trees -  I salute these  fellow nature lovers.

First hunch looking at the top branches vibrating similarly:
- Waves generated at the bottom flatten as they spread and lose higher frequencies sooner. (Similar to water waves.)
- As a tree is a bit like a of chaotic multi-axis pendulum (a rough analogy but shows my point) and thus toward the top vibration becomes more random.
- Branches have their own eigenvectors for resonation and with random incoming vibration they will mostly move along those.

With the above in mind, I would expect slightly different results for different tree types (e.g. spreading foliage with many forks vs tall and lean trees with few forks, shaking at the bottom vs shaking in the middle, size of the tree, strength/amplitude of shaking). The better the waves can flatten, the closer to own resonances at the tip should be.

I think that shaking tree is not as good idea for diploma as it seems. You just have to remember that although it looks like 2d oscilation there are actually 2 3d waves. At every branching wave gets more linear (like AC in electricity). Other artifacts like wiggling at the crown is just conservation of momentum - every little turn creates linear wave like on water.

For that reason string instruments like violin have such powerful sound. It is released not only from strings, and holes in resonanse box, but from faces of that box as well.

Destin, you didn't mention in the video that there are 2 weights rotating in opposite direction and I was wondering if you noticed. This is so that vertical vibrations are cancelled out. This is also the reason for the chain, to synchronize the 2 schafts.
The upper shaft also has 2 weights and the bottom one only one lobe (twice the thickness of one on the to) to place the axles closer together and still cancel out twisting vibrations.
